column1: East Orange is a city in Essex County
column2: New Jersey
column3: United States. As of the 2010 United States Census the city's population was 64
column8: which had in turn declined by 3
column10: 552 counted in the 1990 Census. The city was the state's 20th most-populous municipality in 2010
column11: after having been the state's 14th most-populous municipality in 2000.

column1: East Orange had its origins in Connecticut's New Haven Colony. In 1666
column2: a group of 30 of New Haven's families traveled by water to found "a town on the Passayak" River. They arrived on territory now encompassing Newark
column3: the Oranges
column4: and several other municipalities. The area was situated in the northeast portion of a land grant conveyed by King Charles II of England to his brother James
column6: James conveyed the land to two proprietors
column7: Lord John Berkeleyand Sir George Carteret. Since Carteret had been Royal Governor of the Isle of Jersey
column8: the territory became known as "New Jersey."

column1: East Orange was initially a part of the city of Newark
column2: but it was originally known as "Newark Mountains". On June 7
column4: the townspeople of Newark Mountains officially voted to adopt the name Orange. At the time
column5: there was a significant number of people in favor of secession from Newark. However
column6: this would not occur until November 27
column8: when the territory now encompassing all of the Oranges was finally detached. On April 13
column12: 1860 was Orange officially incorporated as a city. Immediately
column13: the new city began fragmenting into smaller communities
column14: primarily because of local disputes about the costs of establishing paid police
column16: and street departments. South Orange was organized on January 26
column17: 1861; Fairmount (later to become part of West Orange) on March 11
column19: 1863; and West Orange (including Fairmount) on March 14
column20: 1863. East Orange was reincorporated as a city on December 9
column22: based on the results of a referendum held two days earlier.East Orange was known
column24: for the shade trees that lined the cities residential streets. This is still evident today as many of the tall trees still stand.

column1: East Orange is officially divided into five wards

column1: Ampere: Anchored by the now defunct train station of the same name
column2: The Ampere section was developed on land owned by Orange Water Works
column3: after the construction of the Crocker Wheeler Company plant spurred development in the area. The station was named in honor of André-Marie Ampère
column4: a pioneer in electrodynamics and reconstructed as a new Renaissance Revival station in 1907 and 1908. Roughly bounded by Bloomfield to the North
column5: Lawton Street & Newark to the east
column7: and North Grove Street to the West.

column1: Greenwood (Teen Streets): So named after Greenwood Avenue and the "teen" streets that run through it. It is often grouped together with Ampere. This area was severely disturbed by the construction of Interstate 280 and the Garden State Parkway. The Grove Street Station of the former DL & W Railroad was located here at Grove and Main Streets. Roughly bounded by 4th Avenue to the North
column2: North 15th Street/Newark to the East
column3: Eaton Place/NJ Transit Morris & Essex Lines
column4: and North Grove Street to the West.

column1: Presidential Estates: Recently designated due to the streets in this area being named after early presidents of the United States. There are many large well kept homes situated on streets lined with very old
column2: very large shade trees in this neighborhood that are characteristic of the northern section of the city. Roughly Bounded by Bloomfield to the North
column3: Montclair-Boonton Line and North Grove Street to the East
column4: Springdale Avenue to the South and the Garden State Parkway to the West.

column1: Elmwood: Located in the southeastern part of the city. Elmwood Park serves this section of the city
column2: with 7 tennis courts on Rhode Island Avenue
column3: a basketball court on the corner of Elmwood Avenue and Oak Street
column4: a swimming pool with a pool house
column7: a softball field and a renovated field house. The area holds one of the surviving Carnegie Libraries
column8: the Elmwood Branch of the East Orange Public Library

column1: Doddtown (Franklin): Named after John Dodd who founded and surveyed the area of the "Watsessing Plain". The former campus of Upsala College is located here. It was converted into the new East Orange Campus High School on the east side of Prospect Street
column2: and an adjacent new housing subdivision. Roughly bounded by Bloomfield to the North
column3: the Garden State Parkway to the East
column4: Park Avenue to the South and Orange to the West.

column1: Portions of the city are part of an Urban Enterprise Zone (UEZ)
column2: one of 32 zones covering 37 municipalities statewide. East Orange was selected in 1996 as one of a group of seven zones added to participate in the program. In addition to other benefits to encourage employment and investment within the UEZ
column3: shoppers can take advantage of a reduced 3.3125% sales tax rate (half of the ​6 5⁄8% rate charged statewide) at eligible merchants. Established in June 1996
column4: the city's Urban Enterprise Zone status expires in June 2027.The main commercial avenues of the city are Central Avenue and Main Street
column5: both of which flow east to west
column6: the latter of which was disturbed by the construction of Interstate 280. Recent efforts have been made to revitalize the commercial area
column7: especially along Main Street and Evergreen Place. New apartments buildings & commercial space have been proposed and built over the last decade. Along South Harrison Street
column8: new apartment buildings have gone up
column9: while existing ones have been updated.

column1: East Orange is governed under the City form of New Jersey municipal government. The city is one of 15 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this traditional form of government. The government is comprised of a mayor and a city council made up of ten members
column2: two representing each of the city's five geographic political subdivisions called wards. The mayor is elected directly by the voters. The ten members of the city council are elected to four-year terms on a staggered basis
column3: with one seat in each ward coming up for election in odd-numbered years.The City Council performs the legislative functions of municipal government by enacting ordinances
column4: resolutions or motions
column5: and is responsible for review and adoption of the municipal budget that has been submitted by the mayor.As of 2020

column6: connecting Newark in the south to Bloomfield in the north. The Parkway is accessible at Interchange 145 for Interstate 280 and at Interchange 147 for Springdale Avenue. Interstate 280 crosses the city from east to west
column7: connecting Orange to the west and Newark to the east.

column1: Local transportation around the city and into neighboring communities is provided by ONE Bus bus routes 24 & 44 and multiple NJ Transit public bus lines
column2: which includes routes 5
column12: and 97.New Jersey Transit operates two commuter rail train stations in East Orange
column13: both located along the Morris & Essex Lines. The East Orange station is located beside the westbound lanes of Interstate 280
column14: directly across its parking lot from East Orange City Hall. Just one mile west up Main Street is Brick Church station
column15: the city's second rail stop and the more heavily used of the two. Both have seven-day service to New York Penn Station in Midtown Manhattan as well as weekday service to Hoboken Terminal.

column1: The Montclair-Boonton Line runs through the Ampere neighborhood of the city on the east
column2: after splitting off from the Morris & Essex Lines just east of the city line in Newark. Ampere station was a former stop on the line near Ampere Parkway & Springdale Avenue from opened in 1890
column3: but closed in 1991 due to low ridership. Residents can use nearby Watsessing Avenue station in neighboring Bloomfield. Another former stop was Grove Street Station
column4: a mile east of Brick Church
